page.title: 01WETHERBY (WEST) INTRODUCTION
page.content: The area west of Wetherby (averaging between 50-80m in height) forms the eastern edge of the Pennines. The main rock is Millstone Grit but in the east there is some Magnesian Limestone - from which Wetherby's notoriously hard water is obtained (the bore-hole is at Grid Reference 381495). The area has been glaciated and there are several glacial melt-water channels trending N-S to the Wharfe Valley which was once a glacial lake. Most of the area is agricultural: intensively managed grassland for dairying and rough grazing land is dominant in the west. Further east arable farming becomes more important (especially barley, wheat, sugar-beet and potatoes). As developments continue Wetherby town is expanding westwards through isolated farmhouses towards the villages of Sicklinghall and Linton.
